data.Name: Terracotta Panathenaic prize amphora
data.Author: None
data.Content: The Euphiletos Painter was trained in the black-figure technique. It is interesting to compare the firm, deliberate incision in his works with the looser, freer line of artists like the Berlin Painter. The footrace is one of the earliest known events in the Panathenaic games.

data.Name: The marathon boy
data.Author: None
data.Content: The Museum suggests that the subject is the winner of an athletic competition. With its soft musculature and exaggerated contrapposto, its style is associated with the school of Praxiteles.

data.Name: Pericles with the Corinthian helmet
data.Author: Max Kunze
data.Content: The Roman copies of the bust of Pericles derive from a bronze statue made by the sculptor Kresilas. This life-size statue was probably installed on the Athenian Acropolis at or shortly after the death of the politician.

data.Name: Variant of the Head of the Aphrodite of Cnidos
data.Author: Nicolas Koutoulakis
data.Content: This female head is slightly over life-size. The back of the head is a wedge-shaped flat surface with cuttings for the attachment of separately carved pieces that would have completed the anatomy of the head. The eyes are almond shaped and hollowed out for inlay.

data.Name: Torso of the Diadoumenos
data.Author: None
data.Content: This powerful torso was part of a copy of the "Diadoumenos," a Greek statue by the famous master sculptor Polykleitos that has not survived. The original depicted a youthful nude athlete with both arms raised to tie a ribbon, the prize of athletic victory, around his head. The statue was much admired for the skillful representation of the musculature of the chest and the naturalistic and supple pose.

data.Name: Venus de Milo
data.Author: Alexandros of Antioch
data.Content: Aphrodite of Milos (Greek: Αφροδίτη της Μήλου, Aphroditi tis Milou), better known as the Venus de Milo, is an ancient Greekstatue and one of the most famous works of ancient Greek sculpture. Initially it was attributed to the sculptor Praxiteles, however from an inscription that was on its plinth, the statue is thought to be the work of Alexandros of Antioch

data.Name: greek_woman_torso
data.Author: None
data.Content: Reproduction of sculpture of a Green woman. Statue of great quality in reconstituted marble (marble with resin powder). Completion of archaeological aspect.Metal base

data.Name: Marble statue of a kouros (youth)
data.Author: Fletcher Fund
data.Content: This is one of the earliest marble statues of a human figure carved in Attica. The rigid stance, with the left leg forward and arms at the side, was derived from Egyptian art. The pose provided a clear, simple formula that was used by Greek sculptors throughout the sixth century B.C.

data.Name: Lucius Verus
data.Author: Venus de Milo
data.Content: Lucius Verus (Latin: Lucius Aurelius Verus Augustus; 15 December 130 – 169) was the co-emperor of Rome with his adoptive brother Marcus Aurelius from 161 until his own death in 169.
